channel.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
channel.description:
I want to get into programming, especially for Android. Whenever I go on these forums, I always see people programming their own stuff, whether it be a private server, website etc. And from what I've seen, the age range of users on here is like 14-20 right? To me, its impressive that a 15 year old kid is coding his own software. So I want advice from you guys.
When you guys had absolutely no information about programming, where did you start? Did you take classes, or teach yourself? What language did you start with? I read somewhere and it said it'd be easiest to start off with html, xhtml, css, javascript, and then work into BASIC and c# Would you guys recommend that? Is there any other advice you can give me?

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx
item.description:
@peterbjornx wrote:

Well, i started learning BASIC back in '02 when i found Microsoft QBasic on its HDD, after that i learned basic C and Java and i got into RSPS in the school year of '05-'06, after that i thought myself better programming habits and skills from many sources and i got into OS development

Read full topic
item.source: Where did you guys learn programming?

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

I taught myself a lot of what I know. I was (and still am) curious about how things work.

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[quote=“BloodRayne, post:18, topic:404915”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=501928.msg3750670#msg3750670 date=1316013982]
I disagree on both points, HTML is pretty far from plaintext, its very crufty. And it doesn’t teach you a jot about how programming language is structured, its just markup, there’s no flow or anything nomsain
[/quote]
please do go into detail because I don’t see it, maybe if you are including javascript…

Idk, html was my gateway drug, it seemed to give me a pretty basic understanding of how things work in general[/quote]

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

BloodRayne:

I think the majority of people started with html because it’s the most basic practically plaintext language there is, and it gives you a taste for how code is structured, from there you can move on to other bigger and better languages.

I disagree on both points, HTML is pretty far from plaintext, its very crufty. And it doesn’t teach you a jot about how programming language is structured, its just markup, there’s no flow or anything nomsain

Read full topic
item.source: Where did you guys learn programming?

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

My best tip for learning a programming language is to not do it out of a ‘want’ to learn, but out of a ‘need’ to learn. If you’re trying to learn something just to say you know it, you’re not going to get far. When you’re learning something to build with, you hit all the speed bumps in the road, you have to troubleshoot, you learn the better and more efficient ways of doing something.

I think the majority of people started with html because it’s the most basic practically plaintext language there is, and it gives you a taste for how code is structured, from there you can move on to other bigger and better languages.

The only reason I ever got into anything advanced online was for the purpose of cheating rs that was my ‘need’ to learn

Read full topic
item.source: Where did you guys learn programming?

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @TheCyberMan TheCyberMan
item.description:
@TheCyberMan wrote:

Books, determination, google, self-learning, and time to learn all this.

item.source: Where did you guys learn programming?

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Well, I started out at Moparscape, lol. :o
And then I hit up Sun’s (well, they were Sun’s) online tutorial for Java, and went from there.
Also got my hands on various books, such as Effective Java.

As for C, which I only really got into this year, I did my best to immerse myself in what I believe to be ‘good’ code. So I spent time reading through bits and pieces of the FreeBSD and OpenBSD source trees, the Atheme IRC services source tree, and Freenode’s new IRCD, etc.

Read full topic
item.source: Where did you guys learn programming?

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Mopman:

Depends. HTML5 should be treated as individual components rather than one big standard for the purposes of determining whether it’s widespread enough to use or not. For example, if you were going to use WebSockets you’d have to think carefully perhaps, but the more well supported parts are a lot less of an issue.

You have a point, but thats makes HTML5 features only useful if it is used by all major browsers, and HTML5 become less of a Flash-killer.

OP: http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html if you want to make native Android apps. And you need to learn Java, no need to learn a language before that.

Read full topic
item.source: Where did you guys learn programming?

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Bowser jr:

In Europe and US/CA 99.5% uses Flash player 10. How many uses a HTML5 compatible browser?

Depends. HTML5 should be treated as individual components rather than one big standard for the purposes of determining whether it’s widespread enough to use or not. For example, if you were going to use WebSockets you’d have to think carefully perhaps, but the more well supported parts are a lot less of an issue.

IE6 support is awful across the board, but then also irrelevant… it’s a 10 year old discontinued browser used by a minority of the population. (And also doesn’t support Flash 11)

Read full topic

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:7, topic:404915”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=501928.msg3672248#msg3672248 date=1311013870]
everyone sees the content as you intended (As opposed to HTML5)
[/quote]

Yay, Adobe FUD![/quote]
Has IE 6-9 finally kept up with the rest of the browsers?
In Europe and US/CA 99.5% uses Flash player 10. How many uses a HTML5 compatible browser?
If it is a high amount, I admit I was wrong.

And I would never say you should use Flash over HTML5 when it comes to websites (Because flash-sites are shit)

Hopefully HTML5 will make Flash better, and Flash will make HTML5 better through competition. (And I wouldn’t be too surprised if Adobe Flash CS6 could output HTML5 and javascript.

Read full topic

item.title: Where did you guys learn programming?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

E-books and reading the documentation for the programming language was my method.
AND

Speljohan:

google, a goal and determination.

but most important is determination (That I sadly lack).

Personally I started with Flash/AS 3.0. Not great but it is easy and have some great uses, everyone sees the content as you intended (As opposed to HTML5) and is multi platform (Windows, Linux, Mac, iOS, Android…). But avoid making web-sites with it, but rather web-apps. If you want to make real computer software, stay away.

And don’t waste your time with (X)HTML, CSS and JavaScript if you aren’t going to use them.

Read full topic
